values: I went down to Ojai, but along the 150 which I have not continued along before, and stopped at The Thatcher School where the hike up Horn Canyon starts.  In the shadowed cool, I started in gloves and almost forgot my hat.  It warmed up nicely once out of the shadow, then warmed up slightly too much as I passed into another air layer.  Climbing was still fine, and the air dropped temperature again as I got to The Pines, a campsite just 2.5 miles up from the bottom.  It was cool enough and getting colder as I climbed some more and eventually I started seeing little bits of snow in the shadows.  Then there were big areas of snow and even a little on the trail.  It was still not particularly cold and only got to the lower end of comfortable as I came to the very top of the nearest peak where a repeater site is perched.  After looking around, I started back down, stopping only for a few nibbles to eat and for a drawing.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/131825.html

A bit more rain and maybe Mission Falls will be flowing?  Only one way to find out, and that's to look.  I started up Rattlesnake, since like that loads better than Tunnel, but was determined to see where the use trail just after the first mile went.  I suspected up to the utility road above and it did, with some great views.  At the catway, I continued up in a hope that there would be a use trail connecting that top to Tunnel, but there was only as much as expected, which is none.  I had to go back down quite a way before I could go up a spur I knew connected with the trail.  Once on the spur and Tunnel, I had to avoid mountain bikers.  One of the advantages of Rattlesnake is that they are banned.  It was quite a climb, but I finally got to just above where I'd been on the catway and could get around the one last obstacle to seeing the waterfall.  It was running.  Sort of.  A wet smear showed where water could be.  I continued along the trail to the falls and found there was a noticeable flow to renew the wet smear and a few weeping spots.  It had snowed that far down and a few icy spots remained.  I headed back down, turning down Rattlesnake when I came to it.  At the junction, I did a sketch. When finished, I headed down the canyon.  The lower reaches were cold on the way up, they were warm as the cool of evening invaded the less sheltered areas.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/131340.html

We went out for a short hike, with choices being bluffs or mountains.  The rains have just finished washing the air and there's none for the day, so mountains seems the obvious choice.  Specifically, this meant Knapp's Castle.  We wandered our way down among the steady stream of people out for the view.  The fellow really knew what to pick for a place to put a house. We hiked back up to the road and decided to continue along Camino Cielo at which point I realized we would be heading past La Cumbre Peak and its fire lookout and forced everyone to stop there for another little hike.  The stream of people there was slightly less.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/131267.html

I wanted to do another large watercolor and have rather liked the warm press paper that is my largest.  I got it out and settled down to draw a bit of kelp forest.  First kelp for days, then I claimed some space for fish and filled in the watery blue, then even more kelp.  It took a whole lot longer when I wasn't racing to finish the whole painting in a day as I was when I first used the big paper during the last month for the day's tree.  Eventually I got to finishing the fish and then back to more kelp.  Then I let it sit for a day wondering if I was done, but at the end of it, added a little more.  Then I wondered if it was done for another three days, but those didn't produce more details, so I suppose it is.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/130846.html

After a rather cold night with just barely enough to keep myself warm, I packed up the stuff I'd want dayhiking and gathered the rest in one spot in the campground before heading up the trail some more.  There was a lot of frost along the way, some of it had gathered like snow in places.  There wasn't any for me getting up because it was, as I said, dry there.  The trail seemed the least used between my camp (Upper Matilija) and the next (Maple).  It wiggled a bit extra like bushes were pushing it around.  It crossed the stream not just when rocks on one side forced it to but when it looked like the vegetation on the other side was softer to get through.  Eventually I came to the next camp.  Above that, the trail was quite clear and well used.  I started the last climb to the road and motorcycle trail above and started to get glimpses of the ocean beyond.  The view was great near the top.  The very last bit of trail lost that view, though, and was a bit done for completion rather than it being interesting, but I didn't know that yet because I hadn't finished it.  The road at the top was slushy mud with a few bike tracks and old car tracks.  After a short bit, I started down again, stopping in a couple nice spots on the way down, including one to draw. After another downstream look at the canyon from up on its edge, I continued back down to my camp and packed up the rest of my stuff.  Once heavy again, I headed out.  As it got dark, the wet and cold areas below didn't seem so cold compared to the others.  It warmed up a little as I went lower, and the lower camp was actually quite nice.  I hiked the last bit along the road by a pleasant moonlight.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/130732.html

I headed up the upper north fork of Matilija so that I might finish off the trail in an overnight backpacking trip.  It was frosty in the canyon, but dried out a little as I climbed.  At the first climb, I stopped to draw a bit of the canyon downstream and even a bit of the stream visible nearly directly below. By then I'd already passed by two campgrounds.  I passed by the next and went up the second climb in the canyon, giving view of the little waterfall on the other side of the canyon.  There was a little water, but not much.  After that, the trail was new to me.  It goes over a little bump and then drops back down into the stream where there was a small unsanctioned campsite.  I continued on to the next campground, which looked like it was less used than the others, but it was dry and not particularly cold.  Yet.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/130313.html

Checked the tides online and the site told me they were nearly at -2 feet that very moment.  Well, I must go!  And so I did.  Not as many star fish to be found down there as I was expecting, but I found a few.  There were a few birds finding yummy things among the exposed sea grasses.  I walked the whole time I had light, but wanted to do a sketch from something I saw, so did one at home from my photos and memories. The rocks seemed to be people frozen in a rush to reenter the ocean, especially one line of them.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/130189.html

Up not quite with the sun, I packed up and put together breakfast.  The morning wasn't as cold as I'd expected it to be, based on finding ice in a deep hole in a rock that still had a lot of water in it from the last rain.  I took off to the trail head and started along the trail with quite a bit of warm stuff packed away in my pack.  Getting to the turn off to go up to the peak, I continued on the maintained trail instead.  The trail along the north slope was hard under foot.  A few places it went crunch with each step.  I got to the sign at Haddock a bit more quickly than expected, then backtracked to the high point for a bit of relaxing and lunch. When I was ready, I climbed down off the rocks that from the peak and returned much of the way I had come.  Getting to the first spot the trail meets the ridge after going around the peak, I left it to follow the use trail up to the peak.  I got to the peak a bit earlier than generally hoped and it turned out to be a bit colder than hoped.  I quickly pulled on most of what I'd brought to be warm. As the sun got lower, I could see not only Anacapa and Santa Cruz and Santa Rosa, but also San Miguel.  A little later, I noticed something past the shorter Anacapa islands which is San Nicolas.  Sketching left me with a full sketchbook, although I could have gotten out the watercolor book.  After sketching, I pulled on my gloves as well and kept a little active.  I wanted to see the sunset from the mountain.  The sun sank into the ocean, but it wasn't much as far as sunsets go.  Ah well.  I packed up and returned down the other, more used, use trail down the mountain side in the twilight then drove home.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/129912.html

I decided to hike Haddock, but have and easy but early start by camping up on Pine Mountain the night before.  Of course, as I was driving up, I could certainly stop a place or two to look around and I've been wanting to see what is up Potrero John.  The trail is well marked from the road and has few parking spaces that are often occupied, but the sign seems to just point at a small opening in the rocks.  It is well documented online, so it is easy to know to expect a waterfall up there.  There's even a person who went up to the campsite and was quite happy with the hike, but has replies that they just did "half" the hike.  They went as far as the trail is maintained.  I stopped and made my way up as far as the trail is maintained, which is nearly 2/3 of the way, and then followed my choice of use trails up the rest of the way to the bottom of the waterfall. I tried out my new red for some fall leaves and found it came out hot pink.  Not what I was looking for.  After sketching, I pondered the chute that allows access to more waterfalls above and decided against.  I headed back down instead. A little further along, I stopped at Chorro Grande, which I have hiked completely now.  This time I only hiked up far enough to check the rocks for water.  The waterfall there is quite dry.  Then back to the car. I drove up to the pass the road uses and turned up the ridge road, happily open for another week.  I dodged a few very deep potholes, once driving up the side of the cliff to do so, but everyone else was clearly doing it too.  I dodged a lot of deep holes that didn't drop so steeply at the sides and probably weren't a danger to forward progress.  I dodged most of the last few people on the mountain coming the other direction.  Pine Mountain Campgroud was empty, but I was headed for Reyes Peak Campground.  It had a couple people, but then most of them left too.  In the evening, I spotted a couple headlamps coming up Chorro Grande who camped a little way up the road and there was one more car as well.  There was also a lot of chairs that looked like they were just claiming a site that wasn't really occupied. Being away from the buzz of electronics was nice, but was replaced by the moan of wind through the upper levels of the trees.  The stove tried to get me because it wouldn't pressurize, but I made use of still having the instructions and fixed it quickly.  I settled down on a very thick Thermarest that turned out not to be warm enough to keep the ground from sucking the heat from me, but I'd brought a blue mat into the tent too to put my stuff on, so that was quickly fixed too.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/129637.html

I was looking for a pumpkin bread recipe and find that they come in two categories: quick bread with plenty of pumpkin in it but are really cake, or risen bread that only have plenty of pumpkin if the recipe makes 3 loaves.  In fact, all the risen breads seem determined to make more than one loaf with just a little pumpkin puree.  I just want to toss the ingredients into the bread maker and press start, but that doesn't work for 2-3 lbs of bread.  So I tossed together a white bread with 1 cup of pumpkin and a bit too much spice in the wrong ratio.  I know, "too much" isn't something one should say, but there is a balance that must be achieved.  It was a bit too wet and didn't rise enough and really could use a little more sweet.  I tried with a bit of whole wheat to help take up a bit more moisture and toned down (some of) the spices and doubled the sugar, coming out with something that's very nice indeed.  Well, maybe a little sweet now, but very gobble worthy.

1 1/3 cups white flour
2/3 cups wheat flour
4 tablespoons dried milk or buttermilk
1 tablespoon butter
3-4 tablespoons dark brown sugar
1 teaspoon ginger
1 teaspoon nutmeg
1/2 teaspoon cloves
2 teaspoons cinnamon
1 cup pumpkin
2 teaspoons yeast
1 tablespoon wheat gluten (optional)

Mix it all together into bread in the usual way.  For me that means into the bread maker and hit the dough setting, which includes a 1 hour rise time after the half hour of kneading.  I did have to add 2 tablespoons extra whole wheat to get the right moisture content still.  Pumpkin purees will vary, so you do need to know what to expect moisture wise.  It could probably have used a punch down and a second rise period, as is common with whole wheat breads.

For a loaf, drop the dough, punched down again and shaped, into a greased loaf pan, cover and let rise 45 minutes to 1 hour.  Put it in the oven at 300 °F for an hour, then pull it out and enjoy.  Or let it cool, if you must.  (These are my usual loaf baking instructions, used for the first loaf.)

For rolls, split it into 16 pieces, roll into balls and flatten.  Place them on a greased cookie sheet and score crosswise (cut into them with a sharp knife).  Cover and let rise for 30-45 minutes.  Pop in the oven at 400 °F for 12 minutes.  We cooked them for on the convection setting on an insulated sheet, so it should take about the same for conventional ovens on conventional sheets.

Pumpkin purees vary.  I'm not sure how ours compares to the canned sort.  It is probably very similar.  Ours are obtained thus: Take one carved jack-o-lantern on Nov 1st, split it and bake it, I think for about 4 hours at something in the 300 °F range.  Let cool, scoop out, dump in the blender (updated to Cuisinart), and puree.  The resulting orange stuff gets dumped in pint containers and into the freezer until use.  And that's why our pumpkins didn't get carved until Halloween.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/129355.html

I decided to paint another of the trees I have encountered over the years.  This one lives out on Mt. Hawkins. The area has had a fire and the bark beetles have been helping remove what was weakened or weakening what was about to face fire, so large sections of the moutain are matchsticks and fallen matchsticks.  This one looks like it fell as well, but that didn't take too well. And that is the month of trees, done.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/129203.html

It's been raining a bit, so I've decided upon an umbrella tree.  I also realized that I hadn't made up a tree since the first few days.  Too much work?  It's certainly something I find hard, but the point isn't to do that which is easy.  So I painted what every garden needs, at least for today. These trees may be overlapping, but they don't quite work like ordinary umbrellas.  They direct the water down their branches and trunk to collect near the root.  Of course, that means that you wouldn't want to lean on one in the rain...
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/128999.html

I decided to paint a few trees that I haven't been to visit yet since the Station Fire went through the area.  It hit Vogel Flats very early, which would be mentioned because it is populated, so probably got Trail Canyon very early as well.  A couple miles up it is a waterfall that is a popular destination. It's a bit dry on the sunny side, so not much vegetation there.  The trees hide out in the shade.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/128542.html

I went hiking up Whitaker Peak with thoughts of sunset and moonrise.  The report said there would be 38% cloud cover by 6PM, an hour after the various rising and setting, and I was pretty certain it would be the wrong 38%.  I finally decided to go anyway, and was ready an hour after I really wanted to start.  The hike itself turns out to be quite easy, at least along the generally paved road.  The lookout I read about seems to have vanished totally.  The trouble is, the road doesn't actually go up the peak, so I followed the ridge along to it hoping I would find a better trail down.  I didn't find a better trail down, so had to leave the top before the finish of the sunset show to make sure I had enough light to find my own way down.  The moon made a brief appearance through clouds before it was scheduled to come up, so I guess my moonrise source wasn't very good.  It came out into clear sky as I got to a bit of good trail I had spotted that paralleled the road but up on the ridge where the road was more boring, so I hiked that.  Rejoining the road, the moon was starting to get shrouded again, but the only thing left was to roll on down the smooth road.  Pockets of air were warm while other pockets were crisp with cold as I made my way.  The clouds generally just served to make things more beautiful, so it was very much worth going in spite of the weather coming up tomorrow.

After getting home, I found a moment to sketch a couple trees.  There aren't many trees up on the mountain, and those are almost all oaks in sheltered spots.  But I found these in a particularly steep and tight north facing fold on the mountain.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/128374.html

Right... thought to do something odd, like a cardboard tree, but then decided on a rather ordinary tree with a fort built up in it.



So now that's what I have.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/128088.html

I have been wanting to see how this would turn out in acrylic instead of watercolor...



It certainly has its differences... it seems to have lost a little weight.  I think that's partly because I was overly happy with the background and didn't want to cover over the trees.  I shouldn't do that.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/127909.html

Was listening to A Prairie Home Companion by way of the BBC's delayed episodes, which got me thinking about trees on the prairie, but eventually I got distracted by the thought of the trees that are planted as wind breaks along the edges of farms.  I didn't find anything to use as reference, and quite likely it shows... but at least I'm no longer a little scared by the hot press paper just because it has so much texture.  It's actually kind of nice to use.



So that's today's tree.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/127556.html

I've been thinking I would do the iconic lone cypress, and today that's what I did.



There's some good and some bad about this bit of watercolor... a mixed bag.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/127467.html

I wanted to do a tree looking up from near the bottom toward the top with lots of foreshortening.  The first set of photos I looked for such a tree in had one that was just a stump.  A very tall redwood stump, because even broken redwoods are impressive.  I went for that one.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/127130.html

I decided to paint the residents of the area below the sheer north face of Strawberry Peak.



These trees had a tendency toward ponderosa before the Station Fire.  Not just any ponderosa, though.  These produced exceptionally wicked pine cones with long spikes sticking out from the blades of a cone that neared the size of the average hiker's head.  The area is still closed, so I still don't know their fate.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/126764.html
I decided to do something a little disjointed and dropped another manzanita onto a 6"x6" canvas board in acrylic.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/126548.html

I hiked up Rattlesnake Canyon to Mission Falls because there was a bit of rain and maybe, just maybe, there would be a bit of water coming over it.  The mountains sucked up just about all the water, though, as is expected of the first really good rain.  I found only a few puddles in the sandstone.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/126361.html

I had a nice soak in a tub with a book, then decided to do a tree soaking in the water with its knees sticking up.



This photography of acrylic with a flash just doesn't work out so well.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/126018.html

I got out the huge watercolor block, a bit of paper measuring 20"x14" marked "rough".  I'm not sure if that means hot press, which is rough in texture.  It doesn't mention anything except that it is mold made, and I've never bumped into one that isn't.  I put down a few trunks of aspens and some leaves and some ground cover and now I have



all kinds of aspens.  Well, they could all be one aspen since they are aspens.  For the trunks, I put down the watercolor thickly on one side, then pulled it out with water to mark the trunk.  Seems to have worked out nicely.  Took quite a few hours to finish off so much paper, even as a fairly simple theme.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/125697.html
I finished off a stump that's been sitting on my watercolor block blocking the use of the rest of it...
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/125493.html

Decided on doing a droopy willow which... didn't really look so great, I think.  The wrong shape entirely to it.  Got the impression that they might be poorly disguised aliens rather than trees.



So that's them...
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/125270.html

I went hiking along Piru out from Hardluck, or at least where the road is closed.  I had tried for a few other hikes, but ended up here.  I had planned to go downstream, but ended up going up.  Along the creek, I found a few trees.



Maybe should have left out the blue rocks, but they're great rocks... and happy with the tree.

Anyway, I found a trail up along the creek and followed it until it forked, then took the right fork where it did and found myself up on the ridge and further along than I'd thought, so kept to the ridge.  I found a few markers up there, including the surveyor's mark for the county boundary.  It was a very good hike, but a little dark at the end.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/125040.html

Suggestions for a tree seem to run to "lemon" from 's silent partner.  So here you go, a lemon tree.  It was planted over ten years ago in the middle of the yard where the swing set used to rest.  Either there isn't enough water (the grass has to fend for itself for most of the summer and all of the winter) or there's too much grass or the dirt is too hard or without enough nutrients... or maybe a few other possible reasons, the tree just hasn't grown in any appreciable way.  It comes up to the knees and puts out lemons on its little twigs.  It looks like it is about to snap any day.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/124878.html

Are palm trees technically trees?  Maybe it depends if you ask a biologist or anyone else in the world.  Close enough for today, if not.



Was getting to miss watercolor.  Watercolor is ever so nice.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/124593.html

Today, I painted a bit of poplar tree that was crossing low over the trail I hiked a few days ago.  The poplar were generally dressed in yellows for the season.  So here is the poplar, ready for its closeup.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/124413.html
I decided to paint something based on a sketch, and what I decided on was a tree sketched a few years ago while at the Wilcox Property.  So here is the cedar, redone from 1 Jun 2010.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/124140.html

I haven't been doing my tree all day, posting up hikes instead.  Well, one hike.  But a second is started as well.  And then I got wondering, well, what exactly does the larch look like from a long way off?  How would I recognise one if I don't even know what sort of tree it is?  Well, it is a conifer and it has, of course, it's own wikipedia entry.  I decided the fountain pen would be a good toy for this one, because why not?  It has been sitting a while, so I had to just push out the old ink and pull up some new to get it to flow nicely.  Still thinking this Lamy Safari is a bit scratchy and dries a bit more than my Pilot Petit, which costs about 12% of the price of the Lamy.  I clicked on I'm Sorry, I'll Read That Again, starring John Otto Cleese, and started at ... the larch.



That's a lot of wiggles.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/123649.html

I've been doing other things than trees, but took a moment to sketch one that I had found on the shore of Bucks Lake.  This is actually a reservoir, and the tree predates the dam.  The water action has removed the topsoil up to where the tree stands.  It has a little behind it, but not much remains.  The roots were interesting to me since they display clearly what the topsoil level used to be while the tree now grows in sand.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/123489.html

I decided to go on a hike up Piru Creek from Gold Hill Road.  A trail starts from the campground and makes its way up at least to another campground in some 4 or 5 miles.  I started at the campground and started working my way along to find the trail at the back of it, eventually finding another parking area and then a road-like thing.  This road came from where the land first opens up into the flat that the campground occupies.  It also was the other side of a fence from where I was walking, and although the wire was removed, I didn't really want to join up with a wide road.  I took a use trail toward the cliffs above the creek instead.  This trail went past some mine workings that I think were slightly east on the map, then dropped into the creek bed.  I thought it might be interesting to go up this and since there was a use trail it should be doable.

As I hiked up the stream, I kept coming upon some very recent looking footsteps that seemed to make the same decisions I made about crossing the stream, but maybe without the going too far along on that side first.  Eventually I came upon a fisherman, but he was slushing through the creek in waders, so probably wasn't the source of the footprints that aimed well for crossing rocks.  I only needed one step into the water, and managed to pick the boot without a hole in it to do this with.  The water was nearly too deep on tip toe, but I made it with minimal water wetting my sock.  I frightened the poor fisherman by trudging up after him.  He was worried some cat might be stalking him.  The canyon was an easy travel from where I met him to joining the trail again.

The trail has narrows down to a single track soon after what might have been the gate to the road to the mine, I eventually discovered.  At this first creek crossing, it is a dirt bike trail.  It does widen sometimes, but is not meant to.  The trail occasionally becomes very rolling, which is quite annoying.  I have a theory about how these come about starting with a puddle.  I stopped along the trail after the second creek crossing and sketched a couple of the golden alders for today's tree.



Not so wonderful, but I was happy with the effect of putting down some leaves as dots, then giving it a wash of color, then laying down some more leaves.  I mixed a bit of the ocher (gold) in for each of the other colors.   After the watercolor sketching, I continued up the trail to a spot where the map shows a tributary with a waterfall.  This waterfall is visible from the trail, so I didn't have to do anything more cross country to see it, or at least it's dry route.  I sketched this as well.



When I was ready, I turned back and followed the trail back down.  When I just about got to that first creek crossing, my water ran dry, but since I'd brought my filter along, I didn't have to take the last 1.5 miles of somewhat hot and quite dry trail being also dry and thirsty.  I followed this trail back along the top of the cliff which allows a view down into the canyon.  I left the trail at the hole in the fence and continued the way I'd come back to the car.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/123222.html

Today I decided to do a watercolor based on a photo I took while hiking over Cottonwood Pass on my way out from the Sierras during my last visit.  I photographed a few of the standing dead trees that are found in the higher elevations.  I expect these are more Bristlecone relatives like those found on Baden-Powell.  They range in twisting from nearly none to once a foot, but all in the same direction.  I selected one that had a pleasant amount of twist to my eye, and a pleasant bit of branching, and a pleasant bit of background, although that is slightly moved and highly abstracted, to paint.



The dead trees weather to a bright look with colors ranging from very dark brown and black to nearly white.  This seems rather muddy in comparison to me.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/122942.html

In celebration of the day, I chose to paint a specific tree in a place I've never been, the Palace of Westminster.  I found a suitable reference on flicker and attached it on a rather large scale.



Painting a 16"x20" board can be achieved in a single day, if the colors are fairly flat with a few details added in on top.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/122807.html

Today, I headed down to Burbank to hike Wildwood Canyon, AKA "the back side of Stough Nature" with the geeks.  I could see a lot more without the thick fog hanging onto everything and didn't slip down without the beams that hold the trail in slick with moisture.  Instead, the twinkling city stretched out below.

I hadn't decided upon a tree and hadn't done one one the hike, but coming back, I saw some of the oaks that grow at particularly water challenged spots along the crests of hills and thought I could do that.  The hills were particularly nice being a smooth golden.  The trees that caught my attention actually had cut grass below them, but that doesn't mean it has to be.  I got out the block of hot press for a bold painting and filled in some large areas of color, then left it for a while to dry while I tried to get a little nap because I was coming down all tired.  The nap didn't happen, but the drying did.  Then I dropped in a few details which took a bit more time, and had myself a tree.



Now I still want that nap, but am quite pleased with the resulting watercolor.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/122371.html

I thought I might go up Dos Pueblos Canyon, but there is a sign on the road saying it is private and there is "no thru travel" on it.  I'm not sure what people could go "thru" to, since it goes up and ends, but I wasn't sure about going up it and no one felt the need to stop and offer a suggestion of the two that passed me.  I wasn't sure I really wanted to go up the road in the shape I could observe it, either.  Those two were driving nice big trucks.

I thought I might go up Arroyo Hondo, which is misspelled on the Forest Service map.  But I didn't manage to figure out where to turn off.  Signs would help.  I found the Arroyo Hondo Preserve, but they aren't looking for anyone to come without previously mentioning they are coming.  It is possible that I should turn up something just after I can see the old highway bridge, which I stopped at on the way back.  I poked around the bridge, crossed the tracks and looked down on the sea wall, and then stopped to sketch the coastline.



Then I turned off at Refugio to head up a road there and return by Camino Cielo.  It is not in good shape and in the canyon, it is very narrow with plenty of traffic coming the other way.  A sign said there was a bridge out in 10 miles so no through traffic.  It is also a nice drive.  I skirted a lot of pot holes, first crossing over the creek over and over again, then twisting back and forth to climb up to the ridge.  There was a road to the right claiming it was unmaintained and so the county had no responsibility for anything that happens to me if I should take it.  Was it Camino Cielo?  I wasn't expecting anything else and the road I was on seemed to start to drop and said that there was a bridge out in 2 miles.  I turned up the unmaintained road and enjoyed the smoother pavement for a little bit.  Then, at the first hill full of communication towers, it ended.  After the last turnoff for communication towers, it got a bit worse.  I really had to pay a bit too much attention to the details of the road to take in enough views.  I stopped a few times along the way.  I didn't notice a couple of trails I was hoping to spot.  I met a motorcycle coming the other way.  He gave me a good looking over and decided to be amused.  A few spots required some first gear work, which probably means I shouldn't be driving it in a car.  Nothing actually endangered the vehicle.  I stopped by a locked gate of a road not indicated by the map that a few have hiked down, and I drew today's tree, which is a spreading oak.



A big truck like the ones that were headed up Dos Pueblos Canyon came down the road while I drew.  She didn't seem to think my car was outlandish on this road.  That seemed to bode well for the rest of the road.  I packed everything up and continued along.  I met a couple walking down the road, then hit pavement again.  They didn't think my car should be on that road at all and were worried about me.  Their SUV was parked at the end of the pavement, which was the start of a hoard of cars.  The gun club was full of cars, and indeed was quite audible at various places while approaching.  People were parked in bunches along the sides and I met quite a few coming up as I went down.  A lot of wiggles on wide road free of pot holes and I was at the pass with an easy drive home.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/122173.html

For today, I decided I wanted to do a tree gripping the cliff.  I could think of two places I'd taken photos that could be used as reference.  The first is of an oak in Eaton Canyon, which is a dead on photo picking up the root system.  While it is a striking tree, I was looking for something more sideways glancing.  The second is a pine tree that is up above the trail down to Devil's Canyon which is practically a mirror of what I was thinking.  So I accepted the idea of using a photo reference and produced



my second tree in the potential month's series.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/121924.html

I'm pondering the idea of maybe painting a tree a day for November.  If I do so, I haven't already missed one day because



I've just painted this invented tree that seems to be dealing with a lot of constant wind.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/121680.html

I decided to hike to the top of Warm Springs Mountain again, but this time I would actually get there by using the fire roads.  They appear the be well maintained in the satellite photos and turn out to be so while walking on them, too.  The mountain bike trail I took for part of the trip up wasn't so well maintained, but it was distinct and only had one major treefall and the bushes still had some channel to them, instead of tunnel.

At the top, I wasn't sure what might be left of the fire lookout.  My hiking book said there was a fire in 1986 that leveled everything on the mountain.  Of the trees that were there, few of the pines looked over 25 years.  A few oaks seemed to have some more years on them, but were down in the canyons.  The old lookout still stands as a tower.  The wooden boards in it generally remain and are fairly solid where they do remain.  A few important bits, like the landing where the stairway turns, are missing.  Someone wrote in the register that they'd "removed the lookout", which is a funny thing to say when sitting in the shadow of the tower.  I guess the boards aren't burned up but the cab is gone, makes it look like the lookout might not have burned.  Or someone replaced the boards when they decided to lash instruments to it.  The wind gauge was spinning crazily.

For my route down, I did have a look at the trail I knew wouldn't be a help to get me down.  Someone had brushed it for at least a half mile, following the old tread very well.  It looked like they were hacking with a knife instead of the usual loppers.  A hunter had made his way along it too, as well as someone enthusiastic about not carrying their plastic bottles back.  Around a corner, and the bushes were suddenly untouched above the old tread.  That was more like what I was expecting.  I turned back, not really wanting to make my way through two more miles of that.  It was hard enough to stick to the tread without battling bushes.

I went back through Necktie Basin instead of taking the trail, really a path along the old fuel break, back up to the top of the mountain.  It was a pleasant stroll, although a bit of a large loop.  That section of road seems totally neglected up to an old gate.  After that, it isn't much better.  Getting back to the road I came in on was like hitting a highway in comparison.

I wasn't going to stop for drawing, but everything conspired to encourage me to right around sunset.  I went along a bit of old road I suspected was there by the way a hairpin turn was to find a nice spot for a snack as the sun set.  I found a good sitting rock and good view with good hills (and the sun setting behind them) so stopped for a few minutes extra.



I left the little half covered spur of road and followed the fire road all the way down again.  The light was failing, but the bright moon was already high in the sky, so no extra light was needed.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/121454.html

I decided to draw a tree that was tall and fictitious.



And I gave it some abstracted, tall mountains to live among.

While at the top of the hill on my Sunday hike, I took some photos of a rather ostentatious pink castle chocked with palm trees.  It drew the eye quite enthusiastically.  I didn't notice at the time, but above this home was something much more understated, but still quite striking in its way.



So this is what occupies the top of the hill.  It may say a few things the castle says, but it just mentions them instead of screaming them.

There's more interesting trees along the ridges in Gaviota and I decided to paint another one.



The golds and oranges and greens don't work so well as the purples did.  But mixing purple into the tree's green made it a better color.

Went way down the coast to just inside Malibu, that city with quite extensive boarders, and hiked with a group in and near Leo Carrillo.  We hiked up the Yellow Hill Fire Road, and then back down hitting a couple peaks that the road missed.  The wind picked up as the heat grew, balancing it out a little, but leaving us quite dry at the end.

On the way back up the coast, I stopped near Point Mugu to play with my brush pens.



The new black brush pen from Kuretake is shorter and stiffer than the Pentel, but is still young enough to work nicely in the wind.  Still, not quite as fun to use.

While working up photos into a trip report, I got a bit distracted by one tree up in a break in the rocks of the ridge and decided I needed to paint it.



The purple and gold seem nice on the rocks.

Determined to find that pedestrian tunnel and the rest of the Sea to Backcountry trail, I stopped at the fire road and poked around a little.  Weaving around the plants by the river, I found it and passed through.  Beyond, there was much poison oak.  I made my way as best I could, trying to follow trail.  At first the trail seemed very clear, but with loads of plant to avoid all around it, some of it head height.  It got a little less so, but I could still see cuts on the branches of the bordering bushes.  Then it started to seem more and more like animal trail and quickly I was forced to just push through the easiest place.  I made my way toward a hill that had seemed to have trail on it in the satellite photos and would be much easier to travel on since it was just dry grass.  I made my way up, turning onto a bit that looked like trail cut, but as soon as it was out to where it was flat, no cutting had been required and the trail vanished again.  I made my way upward to where there should be trail, then seeing all sorts of poison oak up the hill, decided to just follow the grasslands toward the traditional starting point.  I passed a windbreak someone had built of stones and soon bumped into trail.  I continued along it the same direction to fire road, then turned up it.  Fire road turns into trail, possibly at the forest boundary.  Trail branches and does funny things at a saddle and I skipped a small section of it.  I saw below someone had put a "no trespassing" sign along trail that continued down the canyon on the other side of the saddle.  I continued up and found the backside of another.  Maybe someone thinks it's funny on Trespass Trail?  Isn't that name historical?  I continued to the top.

Oh, yeah, and it rained.  A lot while I ate, but my sun hat turns easily to a rain hat by simply remaining on my head.  It was finishing as I left the peak, but I should have waited just a little longer for some good clearing.  Ah well.

Then I went down for what seemed much more than I'd climbed.  I spotted a trail to the side and followed it past one spring that was being collected only to pour out a pipe with holes in it.  This spring isn't actually hot even though it has some of the same white grime I saw in Lassen around it.  I took a photo of the water spouting out the holes in the pipe, and then, slowly, fewer and fewer spouted.  The housing of the spring was quite noisy, but I couldn't look inside to see what was making the racket.  Back to the trail, I followed it to a dry canyon, then took a trail that had branched off downward.  A bit of smell and noise made it clear I'd got to the hot spring.  I felt the water in the pools, but it wasn't very warm.  I remember the runoff at the fire road being warmer when I passed before.  I was expecting the pools to be quite hot.



I headed down and found that the trail I'd come in on had been very close to the junction of the fire roads.  I followed it back, to a sign just past where I'd joined it that indicated a junction with a trail going up the hill and looked for such again, but didn't find it.  A little further, I did find a junction and followed the trail a little way in the direction that wasn't mine, but it just seemed to want to climb.  Along the trail above, there had been another sign indicating a junction that had a trail going down, so these may meet.  I turned back and made my way down again, this time looking to get down to the freeway as much by the grasslands as possible, then follow it back to the pedestrian underpass.  It worked well until I bumped into an old bit of fence.  I followed it down, coming to bushes I had to push through, but others probably had been this way.  Just short of a gate that would never open for me, the barbed wire was loose and the rest of the way to the roadway looked like an easy walk, so I climbed through.  I was only a little way from the underpass, and popped under to the car again.

And it was cleaner than when I left it.  Imagine that?  Parking next to a gravel road and the car is cleaner.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/120059.html

Yesterday, I walked down to Stern's Wharf.  I made a bit of an attempt to go along the beach, but the low tide barely was for the afternoon and was a few hours before, so I couldn't.  Out on the wharf, I went to the end and drew, then walked around a bit.  On the way out, I stopped into the candy shop.  I think we used to get super massive jawbreakers there for four or six bits, but now they've got some packaged (rather than stuff they made) for three and a half dollars.  Bit more than before.  On the way back, I poked around a little more.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/119697.html

I've been painting hundreds of little circles and now I have a square foot of beach.



So there would be a few more feet between the highest water and the highest recent wave and the current wave, but whatever.  Got me a few stones and a few sea shells and all kinds of sea grass on my sandy beach.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/119467.html

Not me, though.  There were a few lobster fishermen out setting or checking their traps while I was out getting reference photos.  The birds always cluster around them although I'm not sure how useful that is to them for these particular fishermen.  Still, they'll collect around any boat.  The Double Dolphin was out too, under sail.  Not sure I've ever seen it under sail before, but it probably had birds collecting too. I got off one photo and used it for reference here.  Wonder why they all wear such big waders.  Maybe it makes more sense when the ocean isn't so flat.
http://veloracat.livejournal.com/119173.html
